title: R44577
content: The House and Senate passed their respective National Defense Authorization Acts for Fiscal Year 2017, containing provisions affecting military personnel. A conference committee resolved differences between the bills, leading to the final bill being signed into law on December 23, 2016. This report highlights selected personnel-related issues of high congressional interest. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2017 was signed into law on December 23, 2016. This report focuses on key personnel-related issues of congressional interest, including authorized active duty end-strengths and previous legislation impacting military personnel. The authorized active duty end-strengths for FY2001 were Army (480,000), Navy (372,642), Marine Corps (172,600), and Air Force (357,000). Congress increased Army and Marine Corps personnel in response to wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, but recent years saw decreases due to troop withdrawals and budget constraints. End-strengths for the Air Force and Navy have been declining since 2001. FY2016 and FY2017 end-strengths were proposed to be lowered in the Administration's budget, with the House approving higher end-strengths than requested. Notable increases were seen in the Army, Marine Corps, and Air Force. The House bill approved higher end-strengths for all services compared to the Administration's request. The Army saw the most significant increase, with an additional 5,000 personnel compared to FY2016. The Marine Corps and Air Force also increased, while the Navy saw a slight reduction but still higher than the Administration's request. The final bill set the minimum end-strengths at a level equal to the authorized end-strengths for FY2017. The overall authorized end-strength of the Selected Reserves has declined by about 6% over the past 15 years, with reductions in Navy Reserve strength. For FY2017, the Administration requested a reduction in authorized Selected Reserves end-strength for four of the seven reserve components and increases for two. The House bill approved higher end-strengths for all services compared to the Administration's request, with the Army National Guard and Army Reserve seeing increases. The House bill approved higher end-strengths for all services compared to the Administration's request, with increases for the Army National Guard and Army Reserve. Congressional interest in military personnel costs and pay raises remains a focus. The House bill approved a 2.1% pay raise for all servicemembers effective January 1, 2017, in accordance with the statutory formula. The Senate bill would have waived the automatic adjustment to basic pay specified in 37 U.S.C. The FY2017 President's Budget requested a 1.6% military pay raise, lower than the statutory formula of 2.1%. The House bill mandated a 2.1% pay raise for all servicemembers effective January 1, 2017, while the Senate bill proposed a 1.6% increase. The enacted bill specified a 2.1% pay raise, effective January 1, 2017. The Senate bill proposed changes to the calculation of Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) for servicemembers, affecting how housing allowances are determined based on paygrade, geographic location, and dependency status. The Senate bill proposed changes to the calculation of Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) for servicemembers, focusing on geographic location and paygrade rather than dependency status. It aimed to base BAH on actual housing expenditures up to a maximum amount for a given location/paygrade and adjust payments for servicemembers sharing living quarters. The new formula would have applied to certain members of the Armed Forces starting January 1, 2018. The Senate proposed changes to the calculation of Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) for servicemembers, focusing on geographic location and paygrade rather than dependency status. The new formula would have applied to certain members of the Armed Forces starting January 1, 2018, and required the Secretary of Defense to submit proposed regulations by March 31, 2017. The Senate proposed changes to the calculation of Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) for servicemembers, focusing on geographic location and paygrade rather than dependency status. The enacted bill requires DOD to provide a report on transitioning to a new pay structure by March 1, 2017, which eliminates BAH and BAS to recruit and retain a high-quality All-Volunteer Force. The conference report discusses the evolution of BAH as an entitlement over the past 20 years. The Basic Allowance for Housing (BAH) has evolved over the past 20 years to provide a housing benefit for servicemembers in high-cost areas. The housing allowance is intended as compensation and the Secretary of Defense is directed to plan for a transition to a salary system aligning with this purpose. The military retirement system underwent changes in the National Defense Authorization Act for FY2016 to modernize and reduce the retirement system. These changes will take effect on January 1, 2018, for eligible servicemembers. The military retirement system changes, effective January 1, 2018, include a reduction in the retired pay multiplier and the introduction of continuation pay as a retention incentive for servicemembers with 12 years of service. This has raised concerns about retaining certain occupational specialties at the mid-career point. The FY2016 NDAA authorized DOD to provide continuation pay at any point between 8 to 12 years of service in return for an additional commitment to service. The House and Senate agreed on a provision (Section 633) allowing DOD to offer continuation pay between 8 to 12 years of service in exchange for a 3-year commitment. This gives DOD flexibility in managing personnel based on retention trends. Additionally, the bill adjusts procedures for calculating continuation pay minimums for active and reserve component members. The Senate bill considered default contributions to the TSP to be to a Roth plan, which was not adopted. Cadets, midshipmen, and reservists in inactive duty status before January 1, 2018, were granted a 30-day election period for the new retirement system. Military servicemembers can receive retired pay after 20 years of service. The Uniformed Services Former Spouses' Protection Act allows state courts to divide military retired pay in divorce cases. The amount of retired pay is calculated based on qualifying years of service. The Uniformed Services Former Spouses' Protection Act (USFSPA) allows state courts to divide military retired pay in divorce cases. Up to 50% of a servicemember's disposable military retired pay may be divisible in a divorce case. Proposed changes would use pay grade and years of service at the time of a divorce court order. The enacted bill includes cost-of-living adjustments in spousal payments. The Uniformed Services Former Spouses' Protection Act (USFSPA) allows state courts to divide military retired pay in divorce cases, with up to 50% of disposable retired pay divisible. The enacted bill includes cost-of-living adjustments in spousal payments, authorized by §641. This provision does not affect divorce settlements prior to enactment. The Survivor Benefit Plan (SBP) provides a payment to surviving spouses of deceased servicemembers, usually 55% of the retired basic pay. Previously, the base amount for those who died on active duty was 75% of their basic pay. Reservists who died during inactive-duty training receive a lower SBP payment. Surviving spouses receiving both SBP and Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC) have their SBP payments reduced by the amount of DIC, offset by the Special Survivor Indemnity Allowance (SSIA). Sections of the FY2017 NDAA addressed these disparities. The Special Survivor Indemnity Allowance (SSIA) is a payment made to surviving spouses to offset the reduction in Survivor Benefit Plan (SBP) payments due to Dependency and Indemnity Compensation (DIC). The enacted bill includes amendments to extend SSIA until May 31, 2018 and allow the Department of Defense to withhold SBP payments from Combat Related Special Compensation (CRSC) when retired pay is insufficient to cover the premiums. Section 646 extends SSIA until May 31, 2018 and allows CRSC to be used to cover SBP premiums. CBO estimates 65,000 surviving spouses will receive SSIA in FY2018. Section 648 requires an independent assessment of SBP effectiveness and comparison with other benefits. The report evaluates the effectiveness of the SBP for survivors of servicemembers, compares benefits with other government and private sector employees, and explores providing survivor benefits through alternative insurance products. TRICARE is the DOD-administered health benefits program for active duty servicemembers, retirees, and their families. Proposed changes include replacing TRICARE Prime, Standard, and Extra options with TRICARE Select and Preferred options with new enrollment fees and benefit structures. The Administration's FY2017 Budget proposed changes to TRICARE health care, including new enrollment fees, deductibles, and co-pays for retirees and military family members. The proposals aimed to replace TRICARE Prime, Standard, and Extra options with TRICARE Select and Preferred options, with increased pharmacy co-pays and an annual enrollment period. Additionally, the changes would reduce TRICARE for Life expenditures by implementing new benefit structures and cost-saving measures. TRICARE for Life is funded through the Medicare Eligible Retiree Health Care Fund, with uniformed services making annual payments. Proposed TRICARE changes include new enrollment fees, deductibles, and co-pays, with estimated savings and costs over a 10-year period. Exceptions are provided for disability retirees, dependents, and survivors, while TRICARE for Life beneficiaries' cost-sharing remains unchanged. The cost-sharing tables for active-duty family members and retirees under TRICARE Select and Prime will be annually indexed to retirement pay increases. The Secretary of Defense was authorized to exclude drugs of little value from coverage based on recommendations by the Department of Defense Pharmacy and Therapeutics Committee. This would result in significant cost savings, with an estimated reduction of $640 million in DOD's pharmacy costs over the 2017-2021 period and $2.7 billion in net health care spending for TRICARE for Life beneficiaries over the 2017-2026 period. Additionally, implementing this measure would reduce accrual payments into the DOD Medicare-Eligible Retiree Health Care Fund by about $1.5 billion over the 2018-2021 period. The Department of Defense announced new policies for maternity and parental leave, extending maternity leave to 12 weeks and seeking legislative action to extend parental leave to 14 days. Parental leave for a servicemember whose spouse gives birth was first authorized in 2009 and is currently for a maximum of 10 days. Adopting servicemembers have been eligible for up to 21 days of leave since 2006. The National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2009 authorized up to 10 days of parental leave for a servicemember whose spouse gives birth. Since 2006, adopting servicemembers have been eligible for up to 21 days of leave. The new policy allows for up to 12 weeks of total leave for the primary caregiver in connection with the birth of a child, and 6 weeks for a primary caregiver in the case of adoption. Secondary caregivers could receive up to 21 days of leave. The Secretary of Defense will define "primary" and "secondary" caregivers for this benefit. Leave must be taken within a year of the event. General and flag officers hold the most important military positions in the DOD. General and flag officers (GFOs) hold key military positions in the DOD, including the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and combatant commanders. The highest-ranking GFOs are generals or admirals with 4-star rank, followed by 3-star, 2-star, and 1-star ranks. Congress limits the number of GFOs in each grade and periodically reviews their duties and compensation. Proposed legislation aims to restrict the rank of service and functional component commanders under combatant commanders. The legislation aims to revise the number, duties, and compensation of General and Flag Officers (GFOs) in the DOD. It includes requirements for service and functional component commanders to hold ranks no higher than lieutenant general or vice admiral. The Senate bill proposes reducing the total number of active and reserve GFOs by 25%, with a focus on higher-ranking GFOs. Additionally, it suggests establishing a new unified combatant command for cyber operations led by an admiral or general. The Senate bill proposes reducing the number of active component General and Flag Officers (GFOs) by 11%, with a focus on higher-ranking GFOs. It also eliminates certain grade requirements in various communities and senior staff positions, allowing DOD to set grades as needed within overall GFO caps specified in law. The Secretary of Defense is required to reduce the total number of GFOs on active duty by 110 positions by December 31, 2022. Chapter 38 of Title 10 U.S.C. addresses the management of active duty officers trained in joint matters. There is debate over the current qualification requirements for joint qualified officers. Joint matters involve unified action by integrated military forces across different domains. The requirements for becoming a joint qualified officer involve completing specific joint professional military education and a full tour of duty in a joint assignment. The length of a joint duty assignment is typically two years for general and flag officers and three years for other officers, but this requirement can be waived by the Secretary of Defense. Both the House and Senate bills aimed to standardize the length of a joint duty assignment at two years for all officers. The House and Senate bills aimed to modify the criteria for joint duty assignments, standardizing the length at two years for all officers. The definition of joint matters would have been expanded to include various duties such as intelligence, fires, movement, protection, and sustainment. The Secretary of Defense would have been given the authority to designate other joint matters. Additionally, the definition of joint duty assignment would have been modified to require the preponderance of duties to involve joint matters. The definition of joint duty assignment was also modified to require the preponderance of duties to involve joint matters.
